comments.body: can you please add comment on what it will do in terms of output redirects. When it runs as part of e2e tests, will we see stdout from this command still in logs?

Yes, the log-wrap function doesn't cause the command's output to be lost.  With this change, the script logs will be a mix of the existing stdout and the added bootstrap step status logs.

So for example, if the script was:

```
function foo {
  echo 'In foo'
}

# Main
log-wrap 'Foo' foo
```

The logs would be:

```
[cloud.kubernetes.monitoring.proto.SerialportLog] { ..., "bootstrap_status":{"step_name":"Foo","status":"STARTED" ...}
In foo
[cloud.kubernetes.monitoring.proto.SerialportLog] { ..., "bootstrap_status":{"step_name":"Foo","status":"COMPLETED" ...}
```

comments.body:
Should the references here have curly braces like so:

```
"${flexvolume_plugin_dir}"
```

Why? They serve no purpose here.

```
$ flexvolume_plugin_dir='foo bar'
$ echo $flexvolume_plugin_dir
foo bar
$
```
Not a technical thing in this case, just for stylistic consistency. Purely a nit.

As there is a severe mix of using {} and not all over the shell scripts already, I will keep it without here just as it currently is on master, and just add the quotes to handle the whitespace & c:o case properly.

there's a massive style mismatch, I think in the past some of us tried to push for always using braces just because a lot of people editing these are not all that familiar with shell and it at least doesn't break anything if you include them superflously.

at this point i'm happy to let shellcheck more or less cover it, consistency is also not as important in cluster/ which theoretically we probably will remove someday totally :tm: (in reality CI depends on it, and getting rid of it is non trivial / not really staffed).

comments.body:
nit: what about this in order to avoid the nesting.

```sh
 if [[ "${container_runtime}" == "docker" ]]; then
    if ! command -v docker >/dev/null 2>&1; then
      docker version
      return
    fi
    install-docker
    if ! command -v docker >/dev/null 2>&1; then
      echo "ERROR docker not found. Aborting."
      exit 2
    fi
    docker version
  elif [[ "${container_runtime}" == "containerd" ]]; then
    if ! command -v ctr >/dev/null 2>&1; then
      echo "ERROR ctr not found. Aborting."
      exit 2
    fi
    ctr version
  fi
}

nesting vs different if conditions (the first "if  ! command -v" should be "if command -v" and the return+exits is a bit confusing), leaving this as-is.

thanks for looking!!!
Dims

comments.body: @freehan I think we should find a way to simplify the code maintenance when bumping the cni version. One option is put the version number in a kube env variable, which will be passed to the network plugin manifest and here. So you will need to just update one place whenever you need to bump the version. What do you think?
If cni is specified then the cni version should be another kube-env field.
I am not familiar with the cni manifest change, so I leave a TODO here, and will coordinate with the cni owner freehan@ to make the change, which will be in a separate PR.
Ideally, we always want to use the latest stable cni version in kubenet. If customer want to specify their own, they can use cni network plugin and bring their own config/binary.
